posts.title: First post
posts.markdown:
Hello there!  
This blog will hopefully chronicle my adventures into the Land of the Rising Sun, depending if I can be bothered to keep it updated. This is my first blog, so please tolerate any violations of blogging ettiquette =)

I will be in California for a week, then Tokyo, Kyoto, Hakuba and Osaka. I leave this Friday on the 28th of November at around 11pm. It’ll be a 10 hour flight to Tokyo, 7 hour rest (!) in the airport then another 10 hour flight to Los Angeles.

Until then I will be shopping for gear that I may still need. This concludes my first test post. Until next time! =)

posts.title: Flight to Japan
posts.markdown:
[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/kmp-wdm5b280001442900-50-045d.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/kmp-wdm5b280001442900-50-045d.jpg)On a plane with Victor, in the EXIT ROW!!! Quite spacy, with lots of leg room too. Hopefully for the next flight we’ll be on exit row as well, but I chose the squishy window seat instead, so I doubt I’ll get it.
Terrible night, hard to sleep. Had some red wine and scotch… on the rocks. Classy, but for someone with my nonexistent alcohol tolerance it overwhelms far too much.
Food was alright, by airplane standards. I look forward to surviving on the [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/kmp-wdm5b280000932900-49-575d.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/kmp-wdm5b280000932900-49-575d.jpg)poor food we’ll no doubt by consuming over the coming 5 weeks.Annoying guy in front me keeps bringing his seat down, attempting to crush my laptop. Almost succeeded the first time when he caught me off guard. Luckily I have adopted a reflex action pushing him back when he does so. The movie that played on the plane was the X-Files. Not being a fan, I just pulled out my EEE and watched Terminator and House. Entertaining, but I was a little tired. 28% battery remaining, about 1 hour. Hopefully I can recharge it on my special seat in the American Airlines flight. 1 hour until arrival at Narita airport. I’ll upload this when I get the chance I suppose. With luck the USA trip will be uneventful, and we come out unscathed in the dangers of America.
posts.html:
On a plane with Victor, in the EXIT ROW!!! Quite spacy, with lots of leg room too. Hopefully for the next flight we’ll be on exit row as well, but I chose the squishy window seat instead, so I doubt I’ll get it.

Terrible night, hard to sleep. Had some red wine and scotch… on the rocks. Classy, but for someone with my nonexistent alcohol tolerance it overwhelms far too much.

Food was alright, by airplane standards. I look forward to surviving on the poor food we’ll no doubt by consuming over the coming 5 weeks.

Annoying guy in front me keeps bringing his seat down, attempting to crush my laptop. Almost succeeded the first time when he caught me off guard. Luckily I have adopted a reflex action pushing him back when he does so.

The movie that played on the plane was the X-Files. Not being a fan, I just pulled out my EEE and watched Terminator and House. Entertaining, but I was a little tired. 28% battery remaining, about 1 hour. Hopefully I can recharge it on my special seat in the American Airlines flight.

1 hour until arrival at Narita airport. I’ll upload this when I get the chance I suppose. With luck the USA trip will be uneventful, and we come out unscathed in the dangers of America.

posts.title: Flight to LA
posts.markdown:
Currently on the plane to LA. American Airlines operates somewhat differently to Qantas but is still familiar enough I suppose.

We were in Japan for about 7 hours of lounging about. Upon entry my camera was detected in the metal detector. Normally I suppose this would be okay but here the Police can’t speak any English, and silently signal and wave you where to go, or tap you on the shoulder without a word. Unnerving. Regardless I found a whole heap of interesting stuff. Multiple bins for efficient recycling, crazy advanced looking vending machines, buying lunch from people who don’t speak English etc. It was awesome! When we bought lunch the waiter will quickly sneak up behind us and give us our food and when we notice him he quietly slinks away and bows to us. Quirky, yet cool. A lot of the bowing and the “irrashaemase!” can be seen throughout. And all these people can speak English (since we’re still at the airport)! I shiver to think of the communication problems we will run into whence I actually enter Japan a week from now. But this gives me an opportunity to practice my failing Japanese.

I’ve also run into several instances of Engrish already, I’ll put a photo up if I get the chance. What else was there… as yes the internet cafes were pathetically slow. I think they are running on 486s or something. Not only that they are heavily Yahoo sponsored, so whenever you try to go into Gmail internet explorer just shuts down. The keyboard is amazingly frustrating too. The space bar is only about 5 cm wide and the rest of the space is used to convert between alphabets (which I kept hitting by accident).

Japan was cool and all, but alas! We had to leave and goto LA. Speaking of an Alas, Alastair does not have his insurance certificate, which is a problem when trying to get past USA customs. We’ll see what happens.

posts.title: Little Boy Blue Motel
posts.markdown:
[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/kmp-wdm5b280006862906-43-425d.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/kmp-wdm5b280006862906-43-425d.jpg)  
Just arrived at LA and the motel we’ll be staying at for the next few days. Kinda old, but livable. What’s more annoying is the fact that the XD card reader is not working. I can’t pull pictures out! I’ll have to buy a new reader or something when I return to Japan. We’ll be here for two days and then head off to Las Vegas. Most of our time here will be spent going to Disneyland and maybe Hollywood if we can afford the exorbitant taxi fares.

The traffic here is extremely bad and about 70% of the cars are four wheel drives. The smog is very prevalent and there is a lot of traffic and road rage. Many many people speak Spanish rather than English, which is quite interesting.

posts.title: Disneyland photos
posts.markdown:
Just came back from Disneyland. Legs hurt like hell after walking… not far at all. I suppose my legs still aren’t well made for walking around. Regardless it was better than I expected!

[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0002.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0002.jpg)  
We dropped by the 7-11 convenience store on the way there. Beer is amazingly cheap!

[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0003.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0003.jpg)  
…And sports drinks bottles are about 2x fatter than the ones in Australia. The Americans must need a lot of hydration.  
~  
Here are some random photos from Disneyland. Interestingly Disneyland seems to use an enormous amount of power. There are lights EVERYWHERE. Its insane. They also constantly have massive shows consisting of fireworks every night.

We also spotted the infamous Disney “Secret” Police, wearing all black and long trenchcoats. They are apparently known for their harsh treatment of do’ers, usually both evil and good.

[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0008.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0008.jpg)  
Victor in front of a VERY bright castle, not noticeable due to the distance.  
[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0009.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0009.jpg)  
More lights!

[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0011.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0011.jpg)  
C-3PO at the Star Tours ride. It was a simulation car thing which swerves and sways with the video. Well and good except for the horrible motion sickness… According to Alas. I didn’t notice too much motion sickness.

[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0015.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0015.jpg)Another enormous castle thing with way too many lights with an innocent bystander forced to take a photo of us. Notice Steven’s bling.

[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0016.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0016.jpg)Nice to know that Americans follow obvious rules. Or not. Don’t underestimate mother mob mentality I suppose.

[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0017.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0017.jpg)Light spam.

[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0018.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0018.jpg)An American dinner. Lotsa meat.

[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0019.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0019.jpg)An alternative American dinner. Lotsa vegies with lotsa meat.

posts.title: Photos in Narita airport and LA
posts.markdown:
Here are some photos I took initially.

[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0013.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0013.jpg)…Real men take photos AFTER they finish their food.

[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0021.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0021.jpg)Ahh leg room in the exit row.

[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0026.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0026.jpg)First impressions in Japan? Interesting bathrooms (or lavatories, as the Americans call it). Every single toilet (well all the male ones as far as I know of course) have little baby seats, so you can stare at the baby while taking a dump I suppose.

[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0027.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0027.jpg)Ahh an advanced toilet. What do these instructions lead to?

[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0028.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0028.jpg)  
A bum spray! Providing a refreshing clean after you’ve done your business. Hot water comes out immediately too!

[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0029.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0029.jpg)  
Water pressure can be set too for those tight-asses (hmm).

[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0030.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0030.jpg)  
And keeping it nice and pleasant to smell too. Always important when you are in Japan I suppose.

[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0031.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0031.jpg)  
A thermostat enabled sink! Took many ages to work out how to turn it on. It seems they have an infrared sensor so the sink automatically turns on when you put your hand underneath.

[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0035.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0035.jpg)  
A really long horizontal escalator for the several short legged asians that need to get past the airport terminal quickly.

[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0036.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0036.jpg)  
Crazily organised recycling bins. We have plastic bottles, glass bottles, food, newspaper and can compartments for recycling. Apparently it makes it much more efficient.

[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0037.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0037.jpg)  
…My first run in with Engrish.

[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0038.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0038.jpg)  
Incredibly annoying Japanese keyboard. Note the spacebar which is absolutely tiny!

[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0040.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0040.jpg)  
Notice Steven checking his pulse. His blood must have been pumping super fast from the excitement maybe?

[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0043.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0043.jpg)  
Japanese vending machines. Takes coins and notes with weird looking drinks. You can also buy travel insurance from the vending machines as well.

[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0044.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0044.jpg)  
Victor testing out some headphones. Seems the headphones aren’t designed for insanely tall people like him. Note the security cord keeping his head down.

[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0045.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0045.jpg)  
Some advanced rice cookers.

[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0047.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/dscf0047.jpg)  
Here is the most advanced one at about 150 bucks. It won an award or something. I didn’t think rice cookers were so high profile. A mini kettle is there too. Could be handy for my trip.

posts.title: Mornin’
posts.markdown: Got up at 10am today. The other guys were sound asleep even at 11am. I kicked them awake and we should be heading off to sample an American McDonalds soon. We will then head to Califonia Venture, the ‘other’ Disneyland, which happens to be next door.
posts.html: Got up at 10am today. The other guys were sound asleep even at 11am. I kicked them awake and we should be heading off to sample an American McDonalds soon. We will then head to Califonia Venture, the ‘other’ Disneyland, which happens to be next door.

posts.title: Disneyland part 2
posts.markdown:
Just returned from Disneyland for the second day.Went to California Venture, the theme parks other half. It wasn’t as good but still had its moments. We went on almost every rollercoaster there, California Screamin’ being one of them. It was pretty cool! The sixth largest rollercoaster in the world I think. (2nd largest in the US, highest and longest upside portion in the world)

Watched the Disney show thing as well as went to the rides I couldn’t before. I couldn’t get any photos today because I left the XD card at home. Regardless, in conclusion after these past few days I can conclude that Disneyland is alot more than just the photos with Disney characters that everone seems to do. The rides are extremely well designed, polished and their MASSIVE budget shows.

The Disney show at the end for instance, is a fireworks extravaganza. Apparently it runs every night, at odds with the preference of people that live close by at Anaheim because of the massive pollution it causes. In addition to this, there are huge fountains which have video projected onto them, creating a floating 3d effect. There were boats, more fireworks, dragon puppet things, boats and fireworks.

posts.markdown:

Cool trees! They remind me of Vice City or Miami or something. We should get those in Perth!

An American McDonalds meal. This is the BEST burger ever! It’s just a meat patty and lots and LOTS of mushrooms and mayonaisse. Just the way I like it.

California! And me with my tourist pose.

posts.title: Going back
posts.markdown: Currently on the bus back to LA from Las Vegas. I have no idea how the internet works on a moving bus, but I’m assuming it is a satellite internet connection or something. Very cool bus this one… It even has power points and little tables (such as those seen in planes) in addition to the standard TV. 2 days in LA then we’re off to Japan!

posts.title: Photos of Las Vegas
posts.markdown:
[](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0049.jpg)
Photos from Las Vegas! We went to Hollywood after Las Vegas and I have to admit it was very underwhelming. I think its because I just came from a massive high class extravagant casino resort, and Hollywood was just a normal city. Las Vegas has several large buildings on the strip (a road housing all the big casinos), each with there own theme. For instance, there is the Tropicana (tropical theme), Caesar’s Palace (roman theme), Excalibur (medieval theme), Paris (french theme) etc. Very interesting.
[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0049.jpg?w=225)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00435.jpg)This is the Rainforest Cafe inside MGM. Yes, the entire wall and ceilings are covered in a rainforest theme. Not only that, there are robotic alligators, monkeys and panthers. There’s also smoke wafting from the edges of the cafe.
[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0040.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0040.jpg)
MGM. Massive sign. Also note the minature statue of liberty and many bright lights. There’s also a mini eiffel tower and mini Brooklyn Bridge. Insane budget! Oh yeah, one of the casinos also has a moat that has boats that take you for tours around the building. The New York New York building also has a rollercoaster that goes around it.
![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0042.jpg?w=300)
Inside MGM is a Lion habitat as well. Lions just lounging around in an enclosed area near the entrance. The Mirage hotel also has super rare white tigers doing the same important thing.
[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0039.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0039.jpg)
The Excalibur. Massive hulking castle casino thing.
[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0037.jpg?w=225)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0037.jpg)
Another view. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0036.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0036.jpg)Inside of one of the casinos. My only photo of it, since apparently you aren’t meant to take photos inside.
[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0046.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0046.jpg)
Fatburger is one of the shops on “The Strip”, which is the single road that houses all the massive buildings. The name Fatburger really enticed me, but I’m too scared to go in since I have no idea what to expect.
[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0047.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0047.jpg)
I think this is Caesar’s Palace. A massive roman building. These guys have way too much money!
![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0053.jpg?w=300)
Inside Caesar’s Palace. This is just the lobby.
![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0048.jpg?w=225)
A miniature Eiffel Tower. No idea why they bothered, except to cater to the Paris Hilton hotel theme.
![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00491.jpg?w=300)
Bally’s Bar with a spiral tunnel thing for an entrance.
![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0050.jpg?w=300)
The Bellagio. This is probably the coolest building. They have huge fountain shows where jets of water move in unison, often shooting skyward as high as the Bellagio itself.
[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0005.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0005.jpg)Fountain thing in action.[](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0002.jpg)[](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0002.jpg)
![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0002.jpg?w=225)
In front of Bellagio before the fountains start.
![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0054.jpg?w=300)
Alastair’s 21st Birthday. Melvin didn’t come. Just went to a bar in one of the casinos.
We went to Madame Tussaud’s wax museum. Pretty interesting.
[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0015.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0015.jpg)Taking on boxers with ease. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0014.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0014.jpg)No idea who this is. Penelope something.[](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0012.jpg)
![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0012.jpg?w=300)
Bring it on, Rock!
![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0026.jpg?w=300)
Sirens of Treasure Island Casino. A boat of scantily clad women and a boat of scantily clad men duke it out. Outside. In the freezing cold.
![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0030.jpg?w=300)
There was huge fireworks, explosions and flamethrowers during the show.
![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0043.jpg?w=300)
We stayed at Luxor hotel. It’s that massive glass pyramid building thing. At night it shoots a huge spotlight into the sky. Because it can.
![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00371.jpg?w=300)
SUV limosines!
![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00492.jpg?w=225)
Random shot..
posts.html:
Photos from Las Vegas! We went to Hollywood after Las Vegas and I have to admit it was very underwhelming. I think its because I just came from a massive high class extravagant casino resort, and Hollywood was just a normal city. Las Vegas has several large buildings on the strip (a road housing all the big casinos), each with there own theme. For instance, there is the Tropicana (tropical theme), Caesar’s Palace (roman theme), Excalibur (medieval theme), Paris (french theme) etc. Very interesting.

This is the Rainforest Cafe inside MGM. Yes, the entire wall and ceilings are covered in a rainforest theme. Not only that, there are robotic alligators, monkeys and panthers. There’s also smoke wafting from the edges of the cafe.

MGM. Massive sign. Also note the minature statue of liberty and many bright lights. There’s also a mini eiffel tower and mini Brooklyn Bridge. Insane budget! Oh yeah, one of the casinos also has a moat that has boats that take you for tours around the building. The New York New York building also has a rollercoaster that goes around it.



Inside MGM is a Lion habitat as well. Lions just lounging around in an enclosed area near the entrance. The Mirage hotel also has super rare white tigers doing the same important thing.

The Excalibur. Massive hulking castle casino thing.
Another view.
Inside of one of the casinos. My only photo of it, since apparently you aren’t meant to take photos inside.
Fatburger is one of the shops on “The Strip”, which is the single road that houses all the massive buildings. The name Fatburger really enticed me, but I’m too scared to go in since I have no idea what to expect.
I think this is Caesar’s Palace. A massive roman building. These guys have way too much money!
Inside Caesar’s Palace. This is just the lobby.
A miniature Eiffel Tower. No idea why they bothered, except to cater to the Paris Hilton hotel theme.
Bally’s Bar with a spiral tunnel thing for an entrance.
The Bellagio. This is probably the coolest building. They have huge fountain shows where jets of water move in unison, often shooting skyward as high as the Bellagio itself.
Fountain thing in action.
In front of Bellagio before the fountains start.
Alastair’s 21st Birthday. Melvin didn’t come. Just went to a bar in one of the casinos.
We went to Madame Tussaud’s wax museum. Pretty interesting.
Taking on boxers with ease.
No idea who this is. Penelope something.
Bring it on, Rock!
Sirens of Treasure Island Casino. A boat of scantily clad women and a boat of scantily clad men duke it out. Outside. In the freezing cold.


There was huge fireworks, explosions and flamethrowers during the show.


We stayed at Luxor hotel. It’s that massive glass pyramid building thing. At night it shoots a huge spotlight into the sky. Because it can.

SUV limosines!
Random shot..

Note their genetically awesome ability to stand on one leg. It is a gigantic glass pyramid thing. I just want to pick up a rock and throw it at it.

posts.title: Hollywood!
posts.markdown:
[](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0075.jpg)
On our last day in USA, we dropped by Hollywood. It took a lot of trouble to get there, and the public transport was pretty scary at night. Hollywood remains underwhelming, mostly because we just came from Las Vegas (the place of overwhelming stuff).
[ ![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0075.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00694.jpg)
This is the La Quinta hotel at LAX. Nice hotel, though very pricy. They use neat USB sticks as keys to open the doors. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0071.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0071.jpg)Spick and span. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0072.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0072.jpg)Hollywood! This is the Kodak Theatre, some fancy place that was closed. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0073.jpg?w=225)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0073.jpg)This is some special Chinese lobby restuarant cinema thing. I think all the stars and actors/actresses walk down here for those big events. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0074.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0074.jpg)The Hollywood sign! Damn far away too, I didn’t bother walking all the way so you’ll have to make do with a photo from this distance.
[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00752.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0075.jpg)Kodak theatre. Let us in!
[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0076.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0076.jpg)
A fearsome traffic light. It has 5 lights, and I have no idea why. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0077.jpg?w=225)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0077.jpg)Zomg! Its a levitating tap! This was at Ripley’s Believe it or not, but we didn’t  go inside. This was just at the entrance. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0078.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0078.jpg)
Ahh it’s Ron L Hubbard’s winter park thing. Scientology is getting more and more powerful! [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0080.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0080.jpg)
Woop! Taco Bell! None to be had in Australia so I just had to sample some.
[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0082.jpg?w=225)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0082.jpg)
Pretty cheap. You buy an ‘el grande’ meal for about 8USD and you get heaps of stuff. End up being about 1USD per taco/burrito thing.

posts.title: Arrived in Japan
posts.markdown:
Just arrived in Japan after a 12 hour flight. Good first impressions of Japan so far, insanely high density population and many many many train stops. Which is good… assuming you know where you’re going.

I’m in K’s Hostel at the moment. A very good place,., but this is the first hostel I’ve been to. Its like… Living with 50 other people. A weird experience, but not unwelcome. Good hostel though, its ranked the highest in Asia. Much cleaner than I expected.

I had some second thoughts about the trip. At one point, I wanted to cut the trip in half, because the exchange rate is too poor. Everything basically costs twice as much. But it seems everyone else is adamant to go through the entire month. Everyone we’ve talked to has said that an entire month in Japan is very long.

[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/kmp-wdm5b280001482905-41-585d.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/kmp-wdm5b280001482905-41-585d.jpg)This is a picture of the ‘lobby’ of K’s. There’s a bunch of people here as well.

[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/kmp-wdm5b280002492902-06-505d.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/kmp-wdm5b280002492902-06-505d.jpg)A Japanese train. Speedy yet bumpy.

posts.markdown: First morning in Japan. Damn its freezing cold. Currently 6 degrees celsius. Went to the shops and got some cheap food for 300 yen… which normally would be cheap but ends up being about 5.5AUD.

posts.title: Awake
posts.markdown:
Been up for the past 3 hours. Jet lag is kind to me. The only problem is that my friends are still asleep and I’m waiting for them to wake up. Next time I’ll just leave on my own or something.
Just went to Akihabara yesterday. Its insanely cool. There’s tech everywhere!
Currently drinking this awful green tea/water mix thing. It tastes just like water, but you get a green tea aftertaste.

posts.title: Akihabara photos
posts.markdown:
[](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0093.jpg)These are some photos when I visited Akihabara yesterday. Gotta love the train system here. Took almost no time to get there, and I assume its the same case for everywhere else. 11am. Friends still asleep. I think I’m going to kick them out of bed next time.
[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0093.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00844.jpg)Apparently this car costs a million dollars. Not bad. Too scared to take a photo any closer in case the car’s owner has ninjas protecting it or something.
[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0087.jpg?w=225)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0087.jpg)Random street shot of Akihabara’s ‘electric town’. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0088.jpg?w=225)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0088.jpg)Half Life 2 arcade! Zomgwtfbbq!  [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0089.jpg?w=225)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0089.jpg)A weird cube light game thing.  [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0090.jpg?w=225)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0090.jpg)
The pinnacle of Japanese technology. Most of the stuff here in the electric town appears to be of crapulent and poor quality but cheap. Not what I was expecting of  Japan. These are mostly the street stores though, the normal stores are generally techy.
![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0095.jpg?w=300)
A big coke can! Nice to know the Japanese have large servings of stuff.
[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0097.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0097.jpg)
Nice to know Japanese also have tiny servings of stuff.
[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0091.jpg?w=225)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0091.jpg)
A light shops. For the light collectors out there. There’s also a electric fan shop. Maybe some people like collecting fans?
[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0092.jpg?w=225)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0092.jpg)
I have no idea what this means. Danger of teleportation? Watch out for briefcase-holding business men shooting out lightning?
[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00931.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00931.jpg)
WOAH! I want that mini netbook laptop thing. It even swivels out and becomes a tablet with a touch screen! If the AUD wasn’t so pathetic, it would be in my hands right now.
[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0094.jpg?w=225)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0094.jpg)
Big town.
[ ](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0097.jpg)
[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00983.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00983.jpg)
In front of the Akiba shop. It’s an enormous 7 floor building housing all electronic things you could ever want.
[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0099.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0099.jpg)
Inside the Akiba shop there’s this unusual device. It checks your eyes to see what strength of glasses you need to buy.
[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0101.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0101.jpg)
Next to the eye checker thing is this. It is a sonic glasses cleaner. Put your glasses in and it’ll shoot sound waves to clean your glasses. Awesome eh?

posts.title: Ueno park
posts.markdown:
[](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0016.jpg)
After an hour of travelling on foot, we managed to reach the Ueno Park. Pretty cool. There was a buddhist shrine there!
Here are some photos I took before we left. Cold and raining today.
[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0016.jpg?w=225)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00014.jpg)Chilling… This was taken from the rooftop of where I’m staying. A cemetary is so close by! A wall has been erected around the cemetary to scare people walking around it I suppose.
[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00021.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00021.jpg)Japanese power lines! Looks different. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0003.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0003.jpg)A shot out across the suburb. The living standards of the Japanese are somewhat poor compared to the suburbia I’m used to in Australia. Rooms are so cramped! [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0004.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0004.jpg)Not only that, here is a picture of the elevator. They’re even more cramped than Japanese rooms. It can hold up to 4 people, 300 kg max. I’m holding the camera on the side of the elevator, so yes, it really is that small. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00051.jpg?w=225)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00051.jpg)Ahh the home of Kumon. I will never forget how you helped and wasted my life at the same time.
[ ![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0009.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0009.jpg)
A temple at Ueno park. Some monks were inside idling by. Probably waiting for clueless tourists or something. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0010.jpg?w=225)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0010.jpg)A monument thing for the graveyard of soldiers during WWII. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0013.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0013.jpg)The actual graveyard. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00141.jpg?w=225)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00141.jpg)This is closer up to the temple. You are apparently meant to write your wishes on the paper things and put them up with the others. Apparently a supernatural power will grant said wishes. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00151.jpg?w=225)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00151.jpg)Trees are held up with bamboo pole things. Looks cool.
[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00163.jpg?w=225)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0016.jpg)The cherry tree here is bandaged up for some reason. I have no idea why. Maybe it was hurt. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0017.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0017.jpg)Peak hour in Ueno. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0018.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0018.jpg)The local fish market! Well I call it a fish market but its a market of all sorts of other stuff as well (including lots of fish). The markets seems to consist of people shouting at passers by. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00191.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00191.jpg)Another view of the market. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0020.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0020.jpg)Crazy little mushroom things.

posts.title: Ginza, Aunkai, Ueno park and ueno zoo
posts.markdown:
[](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0083.jpg)
It hasn’t been that eventful for the past few days. Went to Ueno park and Ginza. We also went to an izakaya (Japanese bar), but we were told to go away. I’m assuming that they did not want foreigners but I’m really not sure. Interesting experience. Regardless, I managed to go to an izakaya the next night. More on that later.
There are some pics of our visit to the zoo in this entry. It was quite fun, except the giant panda “Ling Ling” passed away in April. The panda was one of Ueno zoo’s biggest attractions, so its unfortunate we didn’t get to see it.
I also had my first night of training with the guys at the Aunkai. I didn’t get to do much really, I only managed to do some exercises before my legs were in too much pain. Lots of squatting around and stuff. It was quite an  interesting way of doing things. These guys have a very solid base. The theory seems to focus on stability and structurally sound methods of receiving force rather than using momentum to bat at an object. So what you’d have is a kick, but the difference with the Aunkai style kick is that when it hits something, the momentum of the kicker’s leg is not greatly affected.
Good fun in all, but each class will cost 2000 yen! 2000! That’s 40 AUD per class! I felt sick inside when I heard Akuzawa say that -_-. I’ll try and do it anyway, its a big part of what I came  for anyway.
[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0083.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0022.jpg)This was quite a deceiving meal. At first it looked just like a pork bun. Steamy floury white bun. But imagine my surprise when I ordered it and the lady took it and plonked it in some soup. Then filled up the cup to the brim with soup. To my surprise the steam bun did not actually have any meat in it, nor was it a steam bun. It was just a block of tofu!  [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00231.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00231.jpg)Here are the three of us in the elevator. Victor, Russell and myself. Note how Russell is asphyxiating from the lack of oxygen. Not much space in there. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0024.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0024.jpg)The Japanese are pretty good at conserving space. Here is a double level carpark. Pneumatics or something push the car up after you park it. The only problem is if there is a car underneath you you’ll have to wait for it to leave first. 
There was an even more awesome carpark I saw as well. It was like… a ferris wheel I suppose. Or a multi disc changer. You park your car into a slot and grab your ticket. Your car will be whisked away. When you need your car back you put the ticket in and the machine will bring your car to you! [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0025.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0025.jpg)More engrish! Merry X’Mos everyone! [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00261.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00261.jpg)Ueno Park.
[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0029.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0029.jpg)There was a  temple in Ueno park in the middle of tokyo for some reason. Nice change from the thousands of people and cars and trains blastinng around. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0032.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0032.jpg)The very first stargate. Currently non-functional. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00331.jpg?w=225)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00331.jpg)There are all these wild cats around the temple for some reason. This one was licking and cleaning the wooden pillar. I guess there’s long work hours for cats in Japan too. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00342.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00342.jpg)Trees and nice view. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00351.jpg?w=225)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00351.jpg)A hut thing. No idea what its for.
[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00373.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00373.jpg)Nice view. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00381.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00381.jpg)Nice tree. There are leaves constantly falling. Must be a pain to clean up. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00391.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00391.jpg)Some other guy. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00401.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00401.jpg)More temple stuff. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00434.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00434.jpg)We’re in the park now. A friendly reminder to not shake hands with a bear.
[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00441.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00441.jpg)Don’t feed the monkeys! They might get… pregnant? A bloated stomach? Fever? Not sure what this sign is telling us. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00482.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00482.jpg)A female… creature. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00493.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00493.jpg)A male version. Guess how I know? This one just sat there for the whole time. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00551.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00551.jpg)A bird with its neck bent backwards. Impressive.
[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00571.jpg?w=225)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00571.jpg)Emperor penguins. They were a lot biggeer than I thought. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00601.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00601.jpg)Ueno skyline. [
](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0065.jpg) [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0065.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00681.jpg)You can not re-come in!
[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00693.jpg?w=225)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00693.jpg)We were in Ginza! Classy department stores and stuff… Here was the entrance of one of the shops. They had rose…ball things.
[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00701.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00701.jpg)Apple store! Weird ball seat things. The entire Apple building has Apple’s annoying user friendly concepts. For instance, the lifts have no buttons! One lift goes up one level at a time and cycles, while the other lift goes down one level at a time and starts again too. Annoying, but cool at the same time. Like all Apple products.
[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00722.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00722.jpg)Outside in Ginza. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00741.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00741.jpg)We were in the Sony building for awhile too. These are weird experimental headphone things. The bent wire part goes inside your ears. I’m not sure how this makes it better, but it feels cool. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00762.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00762.jpg)This is the Rolley! It rolls around and flaps its… flaps. It does it all to some external music.
[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00771.jpg?w=225)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00771.jpg)The Sony showroom runs completely on wind power apparently. These signs were on the wall. Sony saves Pingu! [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00781.jpg?w=225)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00781.jpg) [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00791.jpg?w=225)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00791.jpg) [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00801.jpg?w=225)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00801.jpg)Don’t cry Pingu! [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00815b12-06-225d.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00815b12-06-225d.jpg)Ahh Japanese peak hour. Actually this at 7pm. It’s packed! [](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00693.jpg)
[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00831.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0083.jpg)This is on the way back after training at the Aunkai. This was the midnight train. A little full for a sleepy time. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00843.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00843.jpg)One traffic crossing button for blind people, and one for deaf people. How thoughtful!
posts.html:
It hasn’t been that eventful for the past few days. Went to Ueno park and Ginza. We also went to an izakaya (Japanese bar), but we were told to go away. I’m assuming that they did not want foreigners but I’m really not sure. Interesting experience. Regardless, I managed to go to an izakaya the next night. More on that later.
There are some pics of our visit to the zoo in this entry. It was quite fun, except the giant panda “Ling Ling” passed away in April. The panda was one of Ueno zoo’s biggest attractions, so its unfortunate we didn’t get to see it.
I also had my first night of training with the guys at the Aunkai. I didn’t get to do much really, I only managed to do some exercises before my legs were in too much pain. Lots of squatting around and stuff. It was quite an  interesting way of doing things. These guys have a very solid base. The theory seems to focus on stability and structurally sound methods of receiving force rather than using momentum to bat at an object. So what you’d have is a kick, but the difference with the Aunkai style kick is that when it hits something, the momentum of the kicker’s leg is not greatly affected.
Good fun in all, but each class will cost 2000 yen! 2000! That’s 40 AUD per class! I felt sick inside when I heard Akuzawa say that -_-. I’ll try and do it anyway, its a big part of what I came  for anyway.
This was quite a deceiving meal. At first it looked just like a pork bun. Steamy floury white bun. But imagine my surprise when I ordered it and the lady took it and plonked it in some soup. Then filled up the cup to the brim with soup. To my surprise the steam bun did not actually have any meat in it, nor was it a steam bun. It was just a block of tofu! 
Here are the three of us in the elevator. Victor, Russell and myself. Note how Russell is asphyxiating from the lack of oxygen. Not much space in there.
The Japanese are pretty good at conserving space. Here is a double level carpark. Pneumatics or something push the car up after you park it. The only problem is if there is a car underneath you you’ll have to wait for it to leave first. 
There was an even more awesome carpark I saw as well. It was like… a ferris wheel I suppose. Or a multi disc changer. You park your car into a slot and grab your ticket. Your car will be whisked away. When you need your car back you put the ticket in and the machine will bring your car to you!
More engrish! Merry X’Mos everyone!
Ueno Park.
There was a  temple in Ueno park in the middle of tokyo for some reason. Nice change from the thousands of people and cars and trains blastinng around.
The very first stargate. Currently non-functional.
There are all these wild cats around the temple for some reason. This one was licking and cleaning the wooden pillar. I guess there’s long work hours for cats in Japan too.
Trees and nice view.
A hut thing. No idea what its for.
Nice view.
Nice tree. There are leaves constantly falling. Must be a pain to clean up.

We’re in the park now. A friendly reminder to not shake hands with a bear.
Don’t feed the monkeys! They might get… pregnant? A bloated stomach? Fever? Not sure what this sign is telling us.
A female… creature.
A male version. Guess how I know?
Polar bears are cool! But kinda boring to watch. This one just sat there for the whole time.
A bird with its neck bent backwards. Impressive.
Emperor penguins. They were a lot biggeer than I thought.
Ueno skyline.

You can not re-come in!

We were in Ginza! Classy department stores and stuff… Here was the entrance of one of the shops. They had rose…ball things.
Apple store! Weird ball seat things. The entire Apple building has Apple’s annoying user friendly concepts. For instance, the lifts have no buttons! One lift goes up one level at a time and cycles, while the other lift goes down one level at a time and starts again too. Annoying, but cool at the same time. Like all Apple products.
Outside in Ginza.
We were in the Sony building for awhile too. These are weird experimental headphone things. The bent wire part goes inside your ears. I’m not sure how this makes it better, but it feels cool.
This is the Rolley! It rolls around and flaps its… flaps. It does it all to some external music.
The Sony showroom runs completely on wind power apparently. These signs were on the wall. Sony saves Pingu!


Don’t cry Pingu!
Ahh Japanese peak hour. Actually this at 7pm. It’s packed!

posts.title: Shibuya and Akihabara
posts.markdown:
We returned to Akihabara again, since it was the most interesting place. This time, however, we split up into smaller groups. Was very fun. Got souvenirs and talked to some pre-war guy who is an ukiyo-e printer/artist now. I wanted to buy some paintings but the ones I wanted were about 1000 AUD.
Shibuya was insanely packed. We went to what is apparently the biggest crosswalk in the world! Here are some videos.
Before crossing.
[http://www.youtube.com/get_player](http://www.youtube.com/get_player)
During crosswalk
[http://www.youtube.com/get_player](http://www.youtube.com/get_player)
I’ll upload some more pics later

posts.title: Japanese trains
posts.markdown:
I’m really impressed with the Japanese train system. It goes absolutely EVERYWHERE! A lot of people that I know don’t even bother having cars, and just take the train everywhere. The cost is slightly higher than public transport usage in Perth, but you gotta pay for superiority.
The main problem? The trains are so good, EVERYONE uses them. I took at train at peak hour to goto train at the Aunkai (an incredible martial art that requires another post on its own). My precious personal space was gonna as I was crammed into the train with the locals as you can see.
[http://www.youtube.com/get_player](http://www.youtube.com/get_player)
Here is the train station during peak hour. Note this is Ikebukuro, so not that full compared to other ones. But this level of activity does not die down until several hours later.
[http://www.youtube.com/get_player](http://www.youtube.com/get_player)
Peak hour generally runs from about 7pm to 9pm. There’s also a mad rush for the last train at midnight. You see people so overworked they stumbling around. You think they are drunk at first until you realise they’re actually so tired they are falling asleep while standing up! Crazy. One of the sleepy dudes was doing this fearsome zombie walk up the stairs as he kept falling asleep on each step.

posts.title: Akihabara again
posts.markdown:
[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0019.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0019.jpg)Ahh the life of a Japanese local. My personal space was violated! Crushed against a sea of people. Though I am quite impressed, the entire mob moves at a very very brisk pace. If this was in Australia someone in front will randomly stop and the crowd’s movement will be screwed up. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0021.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0021.jpg)Blurry photo of the loyal dog, Hachiko. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0023.jpg?w=225)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0023.jpg)Shibuya at night! It was packed with people. All the shops were closed so I assume they were going to clubs or bars or something. We tried to follow the crowd but weren’t successful. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00241.jpg?w=225)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00241.jpg)More Shibuya. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00181.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00181.jpg)
NEW FLAVOURS OF PRINGLES! As a big fan of pringles, I endorse this ad.[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00171.jpg?w=225)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00171.jpg)Hmm… men’s size clothing for non men clothing. Scary. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00161.jpg?w=225)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00161.jpg) I have NO idea what this ad means. Can someone explain it? [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00152.jpg?w=225)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00152.jpg)I love Laputa! The full model was huge! And its cost was huge too… =( [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00142.jpg?w=225)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00142.jpg)Japanese doors are too short for Victor! We don’t actually know where this door leads though, it was in a really seedy back alley. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00121.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00121.jpg)Remm, a classy hotel. I will stay here when I become rich and famous. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00091.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00091.jpg)Ahh, Yoshinoya can give you a lunch for less than 400 yen. It’s McDonalds for Japanese really. But healthier. With smaller servings. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0011.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0011.jpg)Lots of people smoking around a non smoking sign. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00081.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00081.jpg)Engrish bank. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00071.jpg?w=225)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00071.jpg)I think this is the Sanyo headquarters. Not too cool, but at least I saw it. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0006.jpg?w=225)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0006.jpg)
I have no idea what this is. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00053.jpg?w=225)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00053.jpg)Random Japanese drink. Pretty tasty too! Tastes like Mountain Dew sortof. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00031.jpg?w=225)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00031.jpg)Seedy Akihabara… [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00013.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00013.jpg)Biggest heatsink I’ve ever seen! Computer shops are meh in Akihabara though. Nothing particularly interesting about them. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00023.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00023.jpg)“We support engineers”! Nice to know we’re appreciated. Even in the subtitles of random stores.

posts.title: Today
posts.markdown:
Too lazy to get photos up today. Went to the senso-ji temple today. There was apparently a festival, using these badminton racquet things. Bought a DS USB charger and stylus so I can actually use my DS now! Prayed at a buddhist temple and got a fortune. It was perhaps the worst possible fortune ever. So I tied it on some stick thing so it will go away. Hope it does.
Discovered melon bread too. Pretty cool stuff. 
It was raining quite badly today, so I didn’t end up going out that much. I was hoping to goto Shibuya or Roppongi but the other guys weren’t very enthusiastic so I ended up dropping it.

posts.title: Odaiba
posts.markdown:
Went to Odaiba some on Tuesday. It was mostly the Museum of Innovation and Technology we wanted to check out. For the robots and cool stuff. But to our surprise, they decided to close on Tuesdays! So we decided to just head to Sega Joypolis instead. Its an indoor theme park of games and stuff. Pretty cool, but doesn’t beat a proper theme park.
Odaiba is an artificial island (similar to the one in Dubai), built by the Japanese government during the economic boom some decade or two ago. Apparently they pulled out of the project since the recession and have left it since. The place is sprawling with awesome architecture and stuff, but the place itself is a ghost town! They must be running at a huge loss. Not only that, most of the showrooms and demos in the technology buildings aren’t running. Nothing is on. Its as if they didn’t have enough funding to put stuff on. There may be one or two people in the lobby, with almost no activity, no people going in or out. Its quite disappointing really.
Asakusa was the temple I mentioned earlier. There were some other tidbits too. Here be some photos of the past few days.
[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0007.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0007.jpg)Some fancy bridge. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00052.jpg?w=225)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00052.jpg)Almost every food store has all the demo plastic food in front. This was the most impressive. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00041.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00041.jpg)Joypolis! Lots of joy to be found here. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00022.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00022.jpg)Cat land! There is a dog land just down the road as well. And a dog cafe, where everyone brings in a dog and shares dog stories about dogs. Apparently dogs are the big thing in Japan actually. I think Alastair said there is one dog per person in Tokyo. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00011.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00011.jpg)
Ahh the Tokyo teleport station. If only. I guess they never finished the research for it.
[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0008.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0008.jpg)The bears be crying for some reason! The description suggests its something to do with global warming, but I know its because Odaiba is being neglected by humans. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00091.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00091.jpg)A fake statue of liberty watches over the fake island. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00101.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00101.jpg)Sweet architecture. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00111.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00111.jpg)More architecture. Noone here though. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00122.jpg?w=225)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00122.jpg)A sculpture! Very artistic and meaningful. It says something about how abstract art is pointless.
[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00131.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00131.jpg)Miraikan! This was our destination today, but it was closed. Maybe because they aren’t getting any visitors. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00143.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00143.jpg)Lots of tourists though. This is inside some fancy building. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00153.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00153.jpg) [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00162.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00162.jpg)Inside some fancy building with cool architecture. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00172.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00172.jpg)Its a spaceship!
[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00182.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00182.jpg)Bridge in night action. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00232.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00232.jpg)We’re in Sega Joypolis now. A walking game! Its not on for some reason. Budget cuts maybe? Or maybe the tourists are too fat/unfit to try the game. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00242.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00242.jpg)Stirfry game! I can master my cooking. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00262.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00262.jpg)Snowboarding ride. Very nauseating, but also very fun. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0027.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0027.jpg)You gotta funteract, bitch! … I have no idea what funteracting is. According to the picture, its stomping on the ground, or dancing.
[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0028.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0028.jpg)A punching machine! I’m kindof annoyed actually, the dude before me got like 300Kgw. So I kicked the last one. I’m going to assume that my kick was so powerful that the machine didn’t know what to do and gave me 0. Rather than it being so weak the machine didn’t even feel it. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0031.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0031.jpg)Some random car in the street. Hazard lights are on and keys are still in the ignition. You see this alot in Japan. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00321.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00321.jpg)LED tree! Just like the real christmas! [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00332.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00332.jpg)Polystyrene blocks cut out and sprinkled to look like sand, and paper leaves. Pretty ingenious with the imitations really.
posts.html:
Went to Odaiba some on Tuesday. It was mostly the Museum of Innovation and Technology we wanted to check out. For the robots and cool stuff. But to our surprise, they decided to close on Tuesdays! So we decided to just head to Sega Joypolis instead. Its an indoor theme park of games and stuff. Pretty cool, but doesn’t beat a proper theme park.

Odaiba is an artificial island (similar to the one in Dubai), built by the Japanese government during the economic boom some decade or two ago. Apparently they pulled out of the project since the recession and have left it since. The place is sprawling with awesome architecture and stuff, but the place itself is a ghost town! They must be running at a huge loss. Not only that, most of the showrooms and demos in the technology buildings aren’t running. Nothing is on. Its as if they didn’t have enough funding to put stuff on. There may be one or two people in the lobby, with almost no activity, no people going in or out. Its quite disappointing really.
Asakusa was the temple I mentioned earlier. There were some other tidbits too. Here be some photos of the past few days.
Some fancy bridge.
Almost every food store has all the demo plastic food in front. This was the most impressive.
Joypolis! Lots of joy to be found here.
Cat land! There is a dog land just down the road as well. And a dog cafe, where everyone brings in a dog and shares dog stories about dogs. Apparently dogs are the big thing in Japan actually. I think Alastair said there is one dog per person in Tokyo.
Ahh the Tokyo teleport station. If only. I guess they never finished the research for it.
The bears be crying for some reason! The description suggests its something to do with global warming, but I know its because Odaiba is being neglected by humans.
A fake statue of liberty watches over the fake island.
Sweet architecture.
More architecture. Noone here though.
A sculpture! Very artistic and meaningful. It says something about how abstract art is pointless.
Miraikan! This was our destination today, but it was closed. Maybe because they aren’t getting any visitors.
Lots of tourists though. This is inside some fancy building.

Inside some fancy building with cool architecture.
Its a spaceship!
Bridge in night action.
We’re in Sega Joypolis now. A walking game! Its not on for some reason. Budget cuts maybe? Or maybe the tourists are too fat/unfit to try the game.
Stirfry game! I can master my cooking.
Snowboarding ride. Very nauseating, but also very fun.
You gotta funteract, bitch! … I have no idea what funteracting is. According to the picture, its stomping on the ground, or dancing.
A punching machine! I’m kindof annoyed actually, the dude before me got like 300Kgw. So I kicked the last one. I’m going to assume that my kick was so powerful that the machine didn’t know what to do and gave me 0. Rather than it being so weak the machine didn’t even feel it.
Some random car in the street. Hazard lights are on and keys are still in the ignition. You see this alot in Japan.
LED tree! Just like the real christmas!
Polystyrene blocks cut out and sprinkled to look like sand, and paper leaves. Pretty ingenious with the imitations really.

posts.title: Asakusa
posts.markdown:
[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00581.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00581.jpg)Melon bread! This stuff is really good. I’ve bought like 5 already. Its custard centre is rockmelon flavoured. The outer green bit is flavoured too! [](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00531.jpg) [](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0041.jpg)
Here are some photos of Asakusa. Its about 10 or 20 minutes walk from here. The giant senso-ji temple is here.[](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00341.jpg)
[ ](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00341.jpg)![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00531.jpg?w=300)[Nice to know there are Homey-Gs in Tokyo as well.](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00341.jpg) [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00341.jpg?w=225)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00354.jpg)They put raincoats on the mascots outside the building when it rains! The other day they put santa costumes on them too. Nice to know someone cares about them. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00361.jpg?w=225)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00361.jpg)I’ve found what must be the smallest door in Japan! [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00372.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00372.jpg)Ahh, Asianican hard marching band. Wait, what the hell is Asianican? American/Asians? Or just Asians with bad Engrish? I will never know. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0038.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0038.jpg)The temple! Its pretty big too. The lantern I mean. Today was the hagoita festival. It
[![](http://www.sakura-hostel.co.jp/blog/images/hagoita%20001.jpg)](http://www.sakura-hostel.co.jp/blog/images/hagoita%20001.jpg)These are hagoite. Some paddle thing that blows away bad spirits in preparation for the new year. The fancy ones can cost about 1000AUD. Use with caution.
[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0041.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0041.jpg)Sesame bun! Tastes like batter, bean paste and sesame. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00421.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00421.jpg)Ahh putting incense into the thingo. It does something cool. That’s about all I know. You might guess that I’m not a very strong buddhist. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00432.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00432.jpg)Waiting for lightning to strike… [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0044.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0044.jpg)Gasp! 77! My lucky number twice! How can a fortune with such a number be bad?
[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0045.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0045.jpg)But alas, it was probably the worst possible fortune.
[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00461.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00461.jpg)Blending in with the locals. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00481.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00481.jpg)By disappearing! Monks are behind the screen, doing their resonant hums. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00501.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00501.jpg)Fugu! Blowfish for those of you who don’t know. I don’t see any disclaimers or anything regarding being poisoned by the blowfish though. They must be really confident. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0051.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0051.jpg)Cool plastic fork suspended spaghetti thing. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0052.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0052.jpg)A department store in Asakusa. High tech bathroom scales!
[![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00532.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00531.jpg)Super comfy msasage chairs! I didn’t test it though. Looks comfy. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00541.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf00541.jpg)Mitsuya cider. I found the Sprite counterpart in Japan! I can now drink lots of it. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0055.jpg?w=300)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0055.jpg)Mos Burger! The Japanese McDonalds equivalent. Pretty cool, but the burgers were small, and not cost effective. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0056.jpg?w=225)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0056.jpg)Bikes are big in Japan. Most bikes aren’t locked either. There are too many bikes for thieves to handle anyway, as you can see in the photo above. [![](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0057.jpg?w=225)](http://nii87.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/dscf0057.jpg)Lots of Salonpas products here. Lots of types. Better selection than back home.

posts.title: Snowboarding!
posts.markdown:
Went snowboarding yesterday. Very humiliating, as I kept falling over. Also extremely painful for your wrist and tailbone. I couldn’t get up this morning becauase of how sore I was. But I am now awake and off to do it again. I should really take lessons, but I’m hoping all this youtube watching and forum reading will be enough =)
After 4 days of this stuff I should be pretty good I hope. It looks really fun… when you don’t constantly fall on your ass.

posts.title: Snowboarding 2
posts.markdown:
Completed another day of snowboarding. We were all meant to get up at 630am, but since we were all so tired from yesterday we ended up getting out of the house about 9 or 10am. Snowboarding was much more fun today, I managed to fall about 3/4 as much as yesterday. I’ve also learnt to fall on different parts of my body, so by the end of the week my entire body should be manageable. Right now my tail bone and bum is bruised. Sounds funny doesn’t it? You won’t think so after snowboarding.

Regardless its pretty fun, once you get going. I’m still learning how to turn on the toeside of the board (heelside is okay) and that will take another day or two I reckon. Once I get those two down, I should be relatively okay. I just found out the board actually flexes, so putting the board under torsional flex (torquing it in different directions with either leg) allows turning. It beats falling down at each turn and getting back up like I’ve been doing so far.

Bechtel just sent me an email, saying I get a trip to Brisbane for my graduate induction program. Sweet! Hope its not brutally hard, such as they making me run on a treadmill for 6 hours or something. Or worse, talk to people.
